document.docAuthor: Cho, Geonho, Inoue, Hiromitsu & Lee, Seunghwan
document.masterDocTitle: On Cacopsylla moiwasana (Kuwayama, 1908) (Hemiptera: Psylloidea: Psyllidae) associated with Sorbus (Rosaceae) with new synonymies

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: On Cacopsylla moiwasana (Kuwayama, 1908) (Hemiptera: Psylloidea: Psyllidae) associated with Sorbus (Rosaceae) with new synonymies

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material examined.
2 ♀ , syntypes of
Psylla moiwasana , Moiwa
,
28.v.
(year not given), ( SEHU ) ( Figs. 3–5 )
;
1 ♂ , holotype of
Psylla jezoensis , Jozankei
,
15.vii.1953
, (K. Sasaki ), ( ELKU )
;
1 ♂ , holotype of
Psylla midoriae
, Jyôjyu-sha , Mt. Ishizuchi , Ehime Pref. ,
24.vii.1958
, ( M. Udaka ) ( ELKU )
( Fig. 2 ).

Host plants.
Sorbus japonica (Decne.) Hedlund
( Rosaceae ) ( Inoue 2004 ),
Sorbus alnifolia (Sieb. et Zucc.) C. Koch
(new record),
Sorbus commixta Hedl.
(new record). All of the host plants were confirmed by the presence of immatures.
Distribution. Japan ( Hokkaido , Honshu, Shikoku, Kyushu), South Korea (Gangwon-do, Gyeonggi-do , Gyeongsangbuk-do ) (new record).

Comments. The examination of relevant types revealed no significant differences between
Cacopsylla jezoensis
,
C. midoriae
and
C. moiwasana
, and we propose here their synonymy. The comparison of types of
Cacopsylla jezoensis
,
C. midoriae
and
C. moiwasana
(ELKU, SEHU), and of a large amount of adults and immatures from various regions in Japan (NIFTS) and Korea (SNU) suggests that the three taxa are conspecific. There are no significant differences in the male and female terminalia and also in other structures, viz. genal processes, forewing venation and surface spinulation. In addition to morphological characters we examined also 714 bp mitochondrial COI sequences of several populations from across Japan showing little differences between them (max. 0.8%) (unpubl. data). For this reason, they are synonymised here.
